help.title: Application information
help.sections_hint: Click a header to expand or collapse its content.
help.objective_description: RegressionLab lets you fit experimental data comfortably, accurately, and quickly, with support for uncertainties and report-ready formatting. It is aimed at experimental physics, sciences, engineering, and computing, and is especially useful for students who need to fit data without programming or as a validation tool.
help.advantage_1: â€¢ **Simple setup**: Put your data (Excel, CSV or TXT) in a folder, run the app, and get professional plots and formatted results ready to copy into your report.
help.advantage_2: â€¢ **Fit to known functions**: Fit with predefined or custom functions quickly and directly.
help.advantage_3: â€¢ **Loop mode**: Add data progressively to your file and refit without reconfiguring each time.
help.advantage_4: â€¢ **Multiple datasets**: Fit the same equation to several series (e.g. the same experiment on different days) in a systematic way.
help.advantage_5: â€¢ **Model exploration**: Try several or all functions on the same data to choose the best fit.
help.advantage_6: â€¢ **Multiple platforms**: Available as a desktop app and web (Streamlit), with no complex installation.
help.advantage_7: â€¢ **Highly configurable**: Customise colours, plot styles, and fonts via environment variables.
help.advantage_8: â€¢ **Extensible**: You can add new fitting functions to adapt the application to your needs.
help.advantage_9: â€¢ **Your own formulas**: Define and fit functions with your own mathematical expression from the interface.
help.custom_functions_how:
Select "Custom formula" as the equation type.
1) Enter each parameter name when prompted (one per dialog).
2) Enter the expression in Python syntax using **x** as the independent variable (e.g. a*x**2 + b*x + c).
Optionally, under "Configure initial parameters" you can set initial values and minâ€“max bounds for each parameter.
help.normal_fitting: â€¢ **Normal fitting**: One equation for a single dataset. The most common mode.
help.multiple_datasets: â€¢ **Multiple datasets**: The same equation is fitted to several files or series; useful for comparing replicates of the same experiment.
help.checker_fitting: â€¢ **Multiple functions**: Try different equations on the same dataset to compare models.
help.total_fitting: â€¢ **All functions**: Applies all available equations to one dataset; useful for exploring which model fits best.
help.view_data: â€¢ **View data**: Inspect data without fitting. Transform (FFT, DCT, log, etc.), clean (drop NaN, outliers, etc.), and save or download the processed data.
help.loop_mode: â€¢ **Loop mode**: After each fit you can load another file and refit with the same equation without leaving the application.
help.data_format_named: â€¢ **Headers required**: First row with column names. One column per quantity and one per uncertainty (if applicable).
help.data_format_u_prefix: â€¢ **Uncertainties**: Name uncertainty columns with prefix 'u' + variable (e.g. ux, uy).
help.data_input: â€¢ By default, data files are read from the 'input/' folder. The path can be changed in Configuration.
help.data_formats: â€¢ Supported formats: .xlsx, .csv, .txt (CSV with comma or semicolon).
help.output_plots: â€¢ Plots are saved by default in 'output/'. The folder can be changed in Configuration.
help.output_logs: â€¢ Application log is saved in 'regressionlab.log' (path configurable).
help.r_squared_desc: â€¢ **RÂ² (coefficient of determination)**: Proportion of the variance in y explained by the model. Value between 0 and 1; the closer to 1, the better the fit.
help.r_squared_formula: Formula: RÂ² = 1 âˆ’ SS_res/SS_tot, with SS_res = Î£(yâˆ’Å·)Â² and SS_tot = Î£(yâˆ’È³)Â² (Å· = fitted value, È³ = mean of y).
help.rmse_desc: â€¢ **RMSE (root mean square error)**: Average magnitude of residuals. Lower values indicate better fit; expressed in the same units as the dependent variable.
help.rmse_formula: Formula: RMSE = âˆš[Î£(yâˆ’Å·)Â²/n], with y observed, Å· fitted, and n = number of points.
help.chi_squared_desc: â€¢ **Ï‡Â² (chi-squared)**: Sum of squared residuals weighted by uncertainties. Lower values indicate better fit when uncertainties are well estimated.
help.chi_squared_formula: Formula: Ï‡Â² = Î£ [(yâˆ’Å·)/u_y]Â², where u_y is the uncertainty of each y.
help.reduced_chi_squared_desc: â€¢ **Ï‡Â²_red (reduced chi-squared)**: Ï‡Â² divided by degrees of freedom. A value close to 1 suggests uncertainties are consistent with the fit.
help.dof_desc: â€¢ **Î½ (degrees of freedom)**: Number of points minus number of fitted parameters.
help.dof_formula: Formula: Î½ = n âˆ’ p (n = points, p = parameters).
help.param_ci_95_desc: â€¢ **95% CI (95% confidence interval)**: For each parameter, the range within which the true value is expected with 95% confidence (t-distribution).
help.param_ci_95_formula: Calculation: [Î¸ âˆ’ tÂ·Ïƒ_Î¸, Î¸ + tÂ·Ïƒ_Î¸], where Î¸ = parameter, Ïƒ_Î¸ = parameter uncertainty, and t = 97.5% percentile of the t-distribution with Î½ degrees of freedom.
help.view_data_options_title: ðŸ“Š View Data â€“ Options and modes
help.view_data_pair_plots_body: Click to open a scatter matrix of all variable pairs. If the window is already open, it updates automatically when you transform or clean the data.
help.view_data_pair_plots: â€¢ **Pair plots**: Click to open a scatter matrix of all variable pairs. If the window is already open, it updates automatically when you transform or clean the data.
help.view_data_transform: â€¢ **Transform**: Select a transform from the dropdown and click "Transform" to apply it to all numeric columns. Transforms are applied in place.
help.view_data_transform_fft: â€¢ **FFT (complex)**: Discrete Fourier transform. Returns complex values (real part stored). Use for frequency analysis of time-series data.
help.view_data_transform_fft_magnitude: â€¢ **FFT magnitude**: Absolute value of the FFT. Useful for power spectra and frequency content visualization.
help.view_data_transform_ifft: â€¢ **Inverse FFT**: Reconstructs the original signal from its Fourier transform. Use after FFT to recover data.
help.view_data_transform_dct: â€¢ **DCT (cosine)**: Discrete cosine transform. Often used for signal compression and decorrelation.
help.view_data_transform_idct: â€¢ **Inverse DCT**: Reconstructs data from its DCT. Use after DCT to recover the original signal.
help.view_data_transform_laplace: â€¢ **Laplace (discrete)**: Cumulative Laplace-like transform: out[n] = Î£ x[k]Â·eâ»áµ…áµ (Î±=0.1). Useful for systems analysis and control theory.
help.view_data_transform_ilaplace: â€¢ **Inverse Laplace**: Reconstructs the original signal from the discrete Laplace transform. Use after Laplace.
help.view_data_transform_hilbert: â€¢ **Hilbert**: 90Â° phase shift (imaginary part of analytic signal). Used for envelope detection, AM demodulation, and telecommunications.
help.view_data_transform_ihilbert: â€¢ **Inverse Hilbert**: Reverses the Hilbert transform. H(H(x)) = âˆ’x, so Hâ»Â¹(y) = âˆ’H(y). Use after Hilbert to recover the signal.
help.view_data_transform_cepstrum: â€¢ **Cepstrum (real)**: IFFT of log(|FFT|Â²). Used in speech processing, pitch detection, and echo removal in telecommunications.
help.view_data_transform_hadamard: â€¢ **Hadamard (Walsh)**: Orthogonal transform with Â±1 basis. Used in CDMA, spread spectrum, and image compression.
help.view_data_transform_ihadamard: â€¢ **Inverse Hadamard**: Reconstructs data from its Hadamard transform. Use after Hadamard to recover the original signal.
help.view_data_transform_envelope: â€¢ **Envelope (Hilbert)**: Amplitude envelope |analytic signal|. Useful for AM demodulation and envelope detection in telecom.
help.view_data_transform_log: â€¢ **Log (natural)**: Natural logarithm ln(x). Use for data spanning many orders of magnitude. Values â‰¤ 0 become NaN.
help.view_data_transform_log10: â€¢ **Log10**: Base-10 logarithm. Same as log but in base 10. Values â‰¤ 0 become NaN.
help.view_data_transform_exp: â€¢ **Exp**: Exponential e^x. Inverse of natural log. Use to reverse a log transform.
help.view_data_transform_sqrt: â€¢ **Square root**: âˆšx. Use for variance-stabilizing or count data. Negative values become NaN.
help.view_data_transform_standardize: â€¢ **Standardize (z-score)**: (x âˆ’ Î¼) / Ïƒ per column. Centers at 0, unit variance. Good for comparing variables on different scales.
help.view_data_transform_normalize: â€¢ **Normalize [0,1]**: (x âˆ’ min) / (max âˆ’ min) per column. Scales each column to the [0, 1] range.
help.view_data_clean: â€¢ **Clean**: Select a cleaning option from the dropdown and click "Clean" to apply it. Cleaning modifies the dataset (e.g. removes rows).
help.view_data_clean_drop_na: â€¢ **Drop rows with NaN**: Removes all rows that contain any missing value (NaN). Reduces dataset size.
help.view_data_clean_drop_duplicates: â€¢ **Drop duplicate rows**: Removes rows that are identical to a previous row. Keeps first occurrence.
help.view_data_clean_fill_na_mean: â€¢ **Fill NaN with column mean**: Replaces missing values in each numeric column with that column's mean.
help.view_data_clean_fill_na_median: â€¢ **Fill NaN with column median**: Replaces missing values with the column median. More robust to outliers than mean.
help.view_data_clean_fill_na_zero: â€¢ **Fill NaN with 0**: Replaces all missing values with zero. Use when zero is a meaningful default.
help.view_data_clean_remove_outliers_iqr: â€¢ **Remove outliers (IQR method)**: Drops values outside [Q1 âˆ’ 1.5Ã—IQR, Q3 + 1.5Ã—IQR] per column. IQR = Q3 âˆ’ Q1. Classic box-plot rule.
help.view_data_clean_remove_outliers_zscore: â€¢ **Remove outliers (z-score)**: Drops values with |z| > 3, where z = (x âˆ’ Î¼) / Ïƒ per column. Removes extreme values.
help.view_data_save: â€¢ **Save updated data**: Saves the current (possibly transformed or cleaned) data to a file. Choose CSV, TXT, or XLSX format.
help.view_data_save_body: Saves the current (possibly transformed or cleaned) data to a file. Choose CSV, TXT, or XLSX format.
help.updates_description: The application automatically checks **once a week** for a newer version when you open it. If one is available, a dialog asks whether you want to update. If you confirm, it runs git pull to update the code. Your input, output folders and .env file are not modified.
help.updates_configure: You can enable or disable this in **Configure** â†’ **Updates**. You can also force the check on every launch (useful for testing) or change the URL from which the version is fetched.

config.title: Application configuration
config.restart_hint: Changes take effect after restarting the application.
config.desc_LANGUAGE: Application language code: es (Spanish), en (English), de (German).
config.desc_UI_BACKGROUND: Background colour for windows and widgets. E.g. midnight blue, navy, #2C3E50.
config.desc_UI_FOREGROUND: Text colour in the interface. E.g. snow, white.
config.desc_UI_BUTTON_FG: Text colour for action buttons. E.g. lime green.
config.desc_UI_BUTTON_FG_CANCEL: Text colour for Exit and Cancel buttons. E.g. red2.
config.desc_UI_PADDING: Internal spacing in pixels (horizontal and vertical).
config.desc_UI_BUTTON_WIDTH: Width in characters for buttons like Exit or Accept (wide = 2.5Ã— this).
config.desc_UI_FONT_SIZE: Interface font size in points (large size = 1.25Ã— this).
config.desc_UI_FONT_FAMILY: Font name (e.g. Menlo, Arial). Must be installed.
config.desc_UI_SPINBOX_WIDTH: Width in characters for numeric fields with arrows.
config.desc_UI_ENTRY_WIDTH: Width in characters for text fields.
config.desc_UI_BUTTON_BG: Background color for buttons (slightly different from window background).
config.desc_UI_BUTTON_FG_ACCENT2: Text colour for equation-type buttons. E.g. yellow.
config.desc_UI_TEXT_SELECT_BG: Background colour of selected text. E.g. steel blue.
config.desc_DPI: Dots per inch when saving the plot image.
config.desc_PLOT_SHOW_TITLE: If enabled, the plot title (fit name) is shown.
config.desc_PLOT_SHOW_GRID: If enabled, a background grid is displayed on the plot.
config.desc_PLOT_LINE_COLOR: Colour of the fit line. E.g. black.
config.desc_PLOT_MARKER_FORMAT: Data point shape: o (circle), s (square), ^ (triangle), d (diamond), * (star).
config.desc_PLOT_ERROR_COLOR: Colour of uncertainty bars. E.g. crimson.
config.desc_FONT_FAMILY: Family: serif, sans-serif, monospace, cursive, fantasy.
config.desc_FONT_TITLE_SIZE: Size: xx-small, x-small, small, medium, large, x-large, xx-large.
config.desc_FONT_TITLE_WEIGHT: Weight: normal, bold, light, semibold, heavy.
config.desc_FILE_INPUT_DIR: Folder where data files are looked for (relative to project).
config.desc_FILE_OUTPUT_DIR: Folder where plots are saved (relative to project).
config.desc_FILE_FILENAME_TEMPLATE: Template for plot filename. Use {} as placeholder for fit name. E.g. fit_{}.
config.desc_FILE_PLOT_FORMAT: Format for saving plots: png, jpg, or pdf.
config.desc_DONATIONS_URL: If set, a donations button appears at the end of the Help window. Leave empty to hide.
config.desc_CHECK_UPDATES: If enabled, checks weekly for a newer version when opening the application.
config.desc_CHECK_UPDATES_FORCE: If enabled, always checks when opening (useful for testing).
config.desc_UPDATE_CHECK_URL: URL of remote pyproject.toml to fetch latest version. Leave empty for default.
config.desc_LOG_LEVEL: Logging level: DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, ERROR, CRITICAL.
config.desc_LOG_CONSOLE: If enabled, log output is also shown in the console.
